A lonely walk? Negroes view campus with mixed emotions
By HOLLACE GOLDBERG
"I was shaving in the dorm one day," related a Negro boy, "and I cut myself. A friend who was sitting nearby joked with me and said, ‘Gee, I didn’t know you had red blood. My mother al- ways told me it was blue.’"
Turning to his friend, the Negro youth replied, "Now that you see it’s red, think of all the other lies your mother might have told you."
This is what the Negro some times encounters on campus. But he knows that a jovial return or a friendly innuendo may serve to enlighten a white person’s attitudes and teach him what the black man is like and what he is not like.
Negroes on campus who mix socially and academically with whites and also stay away from large associations of Negroes feel that they are recognized as students--not as "Negro" stu dents. As rapport develops be- tween these Negroes and their white colleagues, race becomes just another topic for dormitory bull sessions and jests.
Two colored girls in Wicomico one day plastered Black Power signs all over their hall. “It was fun," reports prankster Carolyn, a freshman from Baltimore, for in reply to this stunt, the white girls “dressed up in paper bags, pretending they were a (Ku Klux) Klan."
The hooded WASPS sprinkled perfume on the floor in the shape of a cross and set fire to it. “It really startled us!" exclaimed Carolyn.
"We kid around a lot in the dorm," related Bronwyn, a junior. "We sing 'We Shall Overcome.'" Songs and jokes, she says, don’t offend her, for she does not "look on the bad side about what other people say about me."
Some other Negro students find adjustment to College Park diffi- cult. Betty, who is 28 years old, married and a native of Cali- fornia, finds an “extremely hostile" attitude about the campus. “There are certain vibrations you can feel."
Betty recalls an incident she had with an advisor. During registration week, she went to him twice with scheduling dilem- mas. “He was very nasty," she recalled, biting her lower lip and widening her very expressive eyes. “I told him I had to take this course. He threw my (drop add) slip at me... I thought it was terribly unprofessional for an advisor to extend this sort of treatment."
Betty feels that her race did play a causative factor toward this discourteous treatment. “I do have a basis for comparison," she explained. She was raised in an integrated community, has traveled through Europe with her husband, attended San Francisco State College and Hunter College and interdated in her high school and earlier college years.
"I find It extremely difficult to estab- lish any form of communication with some of the teachers and advisors here," she said. “Students, basically, are friendly, receptive, and warm. But, in some instances, there is hesitancy... I don't think they know how to respond to a Negro."
Betty has run into trouble securing rides from the commuters' carpool serv- ice. A few times, she was able to arrange rides over the telephone. However, when she met her future commuting companions they would frequently “begin to make excuses," and Betty had no ride.
Resulting from her academic and social contacts, Betty concludes that, “When you are brought up in an inte- grated situation, you act as an individual. You are not Negro or white. But here ... in the South... and on this campus ... I feel I am treading on white man's territory... This is the first time I feel Negro."
Also noting a discernible line between the races, but holding a different view point is a 28 year-old male student who works full time off campus.
What's so overwhelming about feeling like a Negro, he questioned. “Isn't there a distinction" between Negroes and whites?
With a wholly different frame of mind is Harry, a lively, congenial sophomore who commutes to school and takes photo- graphs for campus publications. “I am not a Negro on a white campus!" he asserts.
"I don't think this is a white campus ... and I don't go for this stuff that the Negro doesn’t have as much chance as everyone else out here. He does."
A native of Wisconsin and formerly a nine-year resident of Little Rock, Ark., Harry says, “Because of the way my family brought me up... I have never felt inferior to anybody. Some Negroes do feel inferior. Some feel mid way."
A Negro who feels cunningly daring is Dave. Dave has skin brown as chocolate, teeth white as snow and a smile that signals immediate rapport with his environment.
“Maryland is a conservative campus," he notes. “You can’t very well walk out of your race. I was told a lot of tales before I came here. ‘You can’t do this. You can’t do that.’ I feel, though, that there is an atmosphere here and an opportunity to participate in just about anything."
Dave has been active in dormitory sports, house rules committee, powder puff football, dormitory parties and homecoming preparations.
Socially, Dave goes out with whites and Negroes. “I've gone steady with white girls, Jewish girls," he said, adding, “I guess I am a gregarious fellow. I interrelate easily." “But I use my intellect before I jump. Every one gets slapped in the face a few times. So you use some discretion."
In class, for example, “If your grade is tottering... and your prof talks with a little bit of a Southern accent... you don’t talk to Sally during the lecture."
Two female Negro students, however, disagree with Dave’s classroom obser- vation. “If you prove yourself to the teacher," feels Bronwyn, “there is noth ing the teacher can do against you."
“I have encountered nothing (prejudi cial) whatsoever," related Kathleen, a junior majoring in marketing and a transfer student from the University of Maryland in Munich, Germany. “I have yet to find an inkling that such a thing exists as far as teaching is concerned."
Rich, a 26 year-old Business Student recalls, “There were a couple of courses I have taken here where I felt I had gotten a raw deal... I have only run across two professors I can really sit down and talk to here in BPA."
Betty, the attractive housewife-student from California agrees. “I don’t expect to get the benefit of the doubt if I am borderline."
Discussing classroom interaction among students, some Negroes find they are stared at if race is discussed during a lecture. Other Negroes notice nothing of the sort.
"The kids don’t stare at me. They don’t even look up," laughed a pretty Junior who commutes to school from Laurel. “If they do, I don’t catch them staring!"
“Sometimes it hits me that I am the only Negro in a class," relates another Negro. "It doesn't make me shrink. I am always working harder because I always feel I have to prove myself to white people. I have to show them that I live as well as they do, maybe better. I am not a dumb, ignorant Negro. I feel that I have to prove this to them."
Though the Negroes on campus have different experiences and perceptions to relate, they generally agree on one com- mon theme. As one freshman comment ed, “When you have more and more contact with Negro people, then you don’t have as many preconceptions. Why? Because the preconceptions all fall apart."
